ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: more on theory, application, and building a positive classroom environment

I learned a lot from this course. I learned more about Indigenous thought and theory, how to apply it, and how it has been applied. This course changed my perspective on many key terms for Indigenous thought and theory, such as sovereignty.
Great introduction to Indigenous theory in a more concentrated formate. Insightful conversations, concise lectures, and relevant projects.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths were the material and the conversation. The guests to class were also excellent and helped make the content more real, such as for Indigenous futurisms. The weakness may be the amount of work; while entirely doable, it left some readings off the side. A strength is also Professor Andrews. She is an amazing professor!
Professor Andrews was the highlight of this course. To have the opportunity to learn from and alongside someone so knowledgeable, kind, and thoughtful was truly a gift.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I learned a lot as an Indigenous person in this class. Professor Andrews makes it clear why certain readings are paired together, and it's a wonderful culmination of readings. The discussions are also excellent. I would 100% recommend it. The readings and the class also introduce topics, terms, and ideas in Indigenous Studies in a very palatable manner.
Yes!!! Professor Andrews is such a kind, considerate, and intelligent professor, that I genuinely enjoyed going to class on Wednesday mornings (and I hate waking up early).
Yes! Any student who is interested in Indigenous theory or would benefit from an additional ER&M elective.

Yes! This ought to be a mandatory class for all Yale students. As a non-Indigenous person, this seminar has been one of the most generative and important classes I've taken. This class has such a broad range and deep focus on anticolonial theory and Indigenous feminisms. Indigeneity is excluded at all levels of academia and at Yale, and this seminar is urgently needed. This class implicates and challenges everything really, from psychology to biology to political science. It challenges the ways that we imagine academic fields (like the hard sciences) as apolitical and divorced from settler colonialism, empire, and racial capitalism. I also really appreciated this class because it talks about practice, too. Theory and practice. All of it is discussed, explored, and felt in this seminar.
